questions.text: A 28-year-old male who has been admitted with symptoms of altered sensorium and hydrophobia, indicating a potential case of rabies, you have obtained corneal scrapings for further investigation. Now, which test would you select to establish a conclusive diagnosis of the condition? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Viral Culture

 

Altered sensorium and hydrophobia is suggestive of rabies which can be diagnosed by viral culture from corneal scrapings.

 

 

Multiple tests in succession/simultaneously are the best. Usually, Direct Fluorescent Antibody test followed by virus isolation/culture is useful.

 

Virus isolation through culture: best specimens are brain and saliva. CSF, corneal smears and centrifuged urine can also be used.

 

Other Options

 

Option A: Serological tests like indirect immunofluorescence are insensitive.

 

Option B: Seller stain for negri bodies can only be demonstrated in brain (pyramidal cells of Ammon's horn, and the Purkinje cells of the cerebellum are the most common site).

 

Option D: Real time-PCR Amplification Detection of rabies virus RNA is highly sensitive and specific. This technique can detect virus in fresh saliva samples, skin, CS, and brain tissues. However, it is not confirmatory test.

 

Educational Objective

 

Viral culture from corneal scrapings is the most definitive test for diagnosing rabies in a patient presenting with altered sensorium and hydrophobia.

questions.text: The blood pressure of a population was tracked from childhood to adulthood. It was observed that those who had lower BP in childhood had low BP in adulthood, while those who had higher BP in childhood had high BP in adulthood. This can be best described as [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Tracking of blood pressure

 

The phenomenon described in the question is known as tracking of blood pressure. This term refers to the tendency for individuals to maintain their relative position within a distribution of blood pressure values over time. Essentially, individuals with lower blood pressure in childhood tend to have lower blood pressure in adulthood, and those with higher blood pressure in childhood tend to have higher blood pressure in adulthood.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rule of halves: This concept refers to the observation that about half of those with hypertension are aware of their condition, half of those aware are treated, and half of those treated are adequately controlled. It is not directly related to the tracking phenomenon described.

 

 

Option C. The WHO STEPwise approach: approach to surveillance (STEPS) is an internationally comparable, standardized and integrated surveillance tool through which countries can collect, analyse and disseminate core information on noncommunicable diseases (NCDs).

 

Option D. Primordial approach: Primordial prevention refers to measures taken to prevent the development of risk factors in a population, thereby reducing the overall incidence of disease. This concept is related to preventing the onset of risk factors and diseases, rather than tracking existing conditions over time.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tracking of blood pressure describes the observation that individuals maintain their relative position within a distribution of blood pressure values from childhood to adulthood. This means that blood pressure levels tend to remain consistent relative to peers over time.

questions.text: Which contrast agent is safe in a patient with renal failure? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) USG contrast agents

 

Ultrasound (USG) contrast agents, specifically SONO (sulfur hexafluoride microbubbles), are safe to use in patients with renal failure. These microbubbles are filled with gas and are excreted via the lungs rather than the kidneys, making them suitable for patients with compromised renal function. Unlike other contrast agents, USG contrast agents do not rely on renal clearance, thereby avoiding the risk of further renal damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MRI contrast agents (Gadolinium-based): These agents are contraindicated in renal failure due to the risk of nephrogenic systemic fibrosis, a serious condition affecting the skin and internal organs.

 

Option C. Iodinated contrast: Commonly used in CT imaging, these agents are contraindicated in renal failure due to the risk of contrast-induced nephropathy, which can further impair renal function.

 

Option D. CT contrast agent: Typically, iodinated contrast is used in CT imaging, which is not safe for patients with renal failure for the reasons mentioned above.

 

Educational Objective:

 

USG contrast agents, such as SONO (sulfur hexafluoride microbubbles), are the only contrast agents safe for use in patients with renal failure as they are excreted via the lungs and do not rely on renal clearance.

choices.text: Asymptomatic aneurysm measuring 4.0 cm in diameter
Aneurysm size greater than 5.5 cm in males
Stable aneurysm with no recent change in size
Presence of a non-pulsatile abdominal mass

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a history of hypertension, coronary artery disease, and a 40-pack-year smoking history presents for routine follow-up. He is asymptomatic and denies any abdominal or back pain. ultrasound performed reveals an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Based on standard management guidelines, which of the following is an indication for surgical intervention in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Aneurysm size greater than 5.5 cm in males

 

Explanation:

 

Elective surgical repair of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is indicated when the aneurysm diameter reaches or exceeds 5.5 cm in males, even if asymptomatic, due to the increased risk of rupture. Intervention is also recommended for rapidly expanding aneurysms or those causing symptoms such as pain or signs of impending rupture.

 

ther Options:

 

Option A. Asymptomatic aneurysm measuring 4.0 cm in diameter: This option is incorrect because aneurysms of this size are managed conservatively with regular surveillance. The risk of rupture is low, and surgical risks outweigh the benefits.

 

Option C. Stable aneurysm with no recent change in size: This option is incorrect as stable aneurysms without rapid expansion or symptoms are not immediate candidates for surgery. Regular monitoring is the standard approach unless size criteria are met.

 

Option D. Presence of a non-pulsatile abdominal mass: This option is incorrect because A non-pulsatile abdominal mass could indicate a number of things, but it's not a specific criterion for AAA surgery. It would require further investigation to determine the cause.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Surgical intervention for abdominal aortic aneurysms is indicated for aneurysms ≥5.5 cm in diameter in men, rapidly expanding aneurysms (>0.5 cm in 6 months), or symptomatic aneurysms. Asymptomatic aneurysms below this threshold should be monitored with regular imaging and managed with risk factor modification

questions.text: A photographer who recently returned from Africa presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, and hemorrhagic manifestations. He died despite treatment, and an autopsy revealed intranuclear Torres bodies in the liver. Which of the following vaccines could have prevented it? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 17D

 

The above clinical vignette is suggestive of yellow fever and the use of 17D vaccine could have prevented this.

 

17D vaccine is a live-attenuated vaccine administered through the subcutaneous route. It is contraindicated in infants less than 9 months of age, in pregnancy, and in individuals with egg allergy.

 

Yellow fever is caused by flavivirus and is endemic to certain parts of Africa and America. It occurs in two patterns: the urban cycle and the sylvatic cycle. Aedes aegypti is the vector in the urban cycle, while Aedes africanus is responsible for transmission in the sylvatic cycle.

 

Patients present with acute onset fever, headache, and vomiting. Jaundice and hemorrhagic manifestations can also be present. Ultimately, hepatic or renal failure can result in death.

 

Torres bodies are intranuclear eosinophilic inclusion bodies in hepatocytes. These are rarely seen in yellow fever. To prevent the establishment of the disease in India, strict vaccination and quarantine protocols for travelers from endemic areas are enforced.

 

Other options:

 

Option B: Nakayama vaccine is used for immunization against Japanese encephalitis. Culex tritaeniorhynchus is the principal vector. There is a sudden onset of fever and vomiting, which later progresses to encephalitis. In India, it was first reported in Vellore and continues to be active in the country.

 

Option C. Weigl's vaccine is the earliest used vaccine against epidemic typhus caused by Rickettsia prowazekii. The main foci of the disease are Europe, Africa, South America, and Asia. Kashmir is the endemic spot in India. Pediculus humans corporis (human body louse) is the vector. Symptoms include fever and chills. A characteristic rash on the trunk and limbs, sparing the face, palms, and soles, may also be seen.

 

Option D. Jeryl-Lynn strain of the mumps virus is used against the disease as a live-attenuated vaccine. It is contraindicated in pregnancy and individuals allergic to eggs. Mumps present as parotid swelling associated with fever and tenderness.

 

Educational Objective

 

The 17D vaccine could have prevented the yellow fever that led to the photographer's severe symptoms and death. This highlights the importance of appropriate vaccination before traveling to areas where yellow fever is endemic.

3 min
5-7 min

questions.text: The time required for preoxygenation before tracheal intubation is?(AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 3 min

 

Explanation:

 

Preoxygenation or denitrogenation is the process of replacing nitrogen in the lungs with oxygen. This is typically done by giving 100% oxygen to the patient for 3 minutes through a tight-fitting mask or by asking them to take 8 vital capacity breaths. This process helps to lengthen the apnea time, providing an improved margin of safety while the anesthesiologist secures the airway and resumes ventilation.

 

There are two main methods commonly used for preoxygenation:

 

  1. The first method involves utilizing tidal volume ventilation through a face mask for a duration of 3 minutes. This technique allows for the exchange of approximately 95% of the gas present in the lungs.
  2. The second method relies on vital capacity breaths to achieve effective preoxygenation in a shorter time frame. While four breaths over 30 seconds are not as efficient as the tidal volume method, it may still be deemed acceptable in specific clinical scenarios. Research has indicated that eight breaths over a span of 60 seconds are more effective for preoxygenation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1 min: This duration is insufficient for effective preoxygenation, as it does not allow adequate time to replace the nitrogen in the lungs with oxygen.

 

Option C. 5-7 min: While longer preoxygenation can ensure thorough denitrogenation, it is not typically necessary beyond the 3 minutes required for effective preoxygenation.

 

Option D. 5 min: Preoxygenation for this duration can be effective, but the standard practice is to use 3 minutes as it is usually sufficient to achieve the desired effect.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Preoxygenation for tracheal intubation is effectively achieved by administering 100% oxygen for 3 minutes through a tight-fitting mask or by taking 8 vital capacity breaths.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 1380

questions.text: Which metal causes the endemic peripheral vascular disease known as Blackfoot disease?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Arsenic

 

  • Arsenic, cadmium, lead and mercury are the heavy metals which can cause peripheral vascular disease due to chronic poisoning. This leads to general clinical features of peripheral vascular disease (numbness in feet, rest pain etc.).
  • Blackfoot disease is a unique term given to peripheral vascular disease produced by chronic Arsenic poisoning. The name "Blackfoot" refers to the characteristic darkening and gangrene of the feet and lower legs. This ultimately leads to amputation.
  • In peripheral vascular disease caused by other heavy metals, gangrene is not a common manifestation
  • Below picture shows Blackfoot disease:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antimony: Antimony does not cause Blackfoot disease. It can cause other toxic effects but is not specifically linked to peripheral vascular disease.

 

Option C. Barium: Barium toxicity is primarily associated with gastrointestinal and muscular symptoms rather than peripheral vascular disease.

 

Option D. Cadmium: While cadmium can cause peripheral vascular disease, it does not specifically lead to Blackfoot disease, which is uniquely associated with arsenic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blackfoot disease, characterized by darkening and gangrene of the feet and lower legs, is specifically caused by chronic arsenic poisoning. Other heavy metals such as cadmium, lead, and mercury can cause peripheral vascular disease, but Blackfoot disease is unique to arsenic exposure.

questions.text: The image of a drug is given below. It is used in which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Subglottic stenosis

 

The given drug is Mitomycin-C. It is used topically in the management of subglottic stenosis.

 

Mitomycin is an antibiotic that is isolated from the broth of Streptomyces caespitosus. This drug has demonstrated antitumor activity. Mitomycin belongs to a group of alkylating agents that work by cross-linking the complementary strands found in DNA. It also has antifibrotic property which prevents tissue scarring.

 

Thus, it can used to inhibit post-surgical scar formation and as a chemotherapeutic agent.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Rhinocerebral mucormycosis - This fungal infection requires antifungal medications, not typically treated with Mitomycin-C.

 

Option C. Adenoidectomy - A surgical procedure to remove adenoids; does not involve the use of Mitomycin-C.

 

Option D. Tympanoplasty - Surgical repair of the eardrum, where Mitomycin-C is not routinely used.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Mitomycin-C is particularly effective in preventing the recurrence of subglottic stenosis after surgery due to its antifibrotic properties, making it a critical adjunct in surgical procedures involving the airway.

 

Ref - Scott Brown 8th edition, volume 3, Page No. 1088

questions.text: In what situations does Gelle's test yield a negative result?(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Otosclerosis

 

  • Gelle's test is negative when the ossicular chain is fixed as in case of otosclerosis.
  • Gelle's test –  Increased pressure in the ear canal by Siegel's speculum, pushes the tympanic membrane and ossicles inwards raising the intralabyrinthine pressure and reducing the mobility of the basilar membrane leading to decreased hearing. This is called as Gelle’s positive seen in normal and SNHL patients.
  • No change in hearing on applying pressure is Gelle’s negative, seen in ossicular chain fixation or discontinuity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CSOM with Cholesteatoma: In case of CSOM with cholesteatoma, the pressure increased by the seigel’s speculum will directly push the cholesteatoma onto the ossicles (there is no fixation of ossicles here) and then there will be increased intralabyrinthine pressure. Hence Gelle will be positive.

 

Option B. Senile deafness: In case of senile deafness (presbycusis), there will be sensorineural hearing loss and it is due to natural aging of the hair cells. The ossicles will be mobile normally and hence Gelle will be positive.

 

Option C. Meniere’s disease: In case of Meniere’s disease also, the ossicles are not involved. On siegelisation, the inward pushed TM and ossicles will raise intralabyrinthine pressure, thereby making Gelle test positive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gelle’s test is instrumental in diagnosing conditions involving ossicular chain mobility. A negative Gelle's test, indicating ossicular fixation, is particularly indicative of otosclerosis, which is crucial for determining appropriate management strategies, including potential surgical interventions like stapedectomy for improving hearing.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 24, 25

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented to the clinic with a complaint of the feeling of insects crawling under the skin. Which of the following drug abuse can cause the symptoms of this patient?( NEET PG 2020 )
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cocaine

 

The sensation of insects or bugs crawling on or under the skin, known as "formication", is classically associated with cocaine use. While it can also be seen with the use of other stimulants, including amphetamines, it is most emblematic of cocaine intoxication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cannabis: Typically results in effects like altered perception, increased appetite, and paranoia.

 

Option C. Amphetamine: Another stimulant that can lead to increased energy, euphoria, and sometimes similar tactile hallucinations.

 

Option D. Alcohol: Produces symptoms such as impaired judgment, slurred speech, and incoordination.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Cocaine intoxication can lead to tactile hallucinations, notably the sensation known as formication. This sensation, often described as feeling like bugs crawling on or under the skin, is a classic symptom of cocaine use and can lead to skin picking and resultant lesions. This is also known as cocaine bugs or magnun phenomenon.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 676.

choices.text: Inability to speak
Stridor during inspiration
None of the above

questions.text: Which of the following is not a sign of respiratory insufficiency?  (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. None of the above

 

Explanation

 

Hypoxia, inability to speak, and stridor during inspiration are all signs of respiratory insufficiency. Respiratory insufficiency occurs when the lungs cannot function properly to maintain normal oxygen uptake and carbon dioxide removal, leading to symptoms such as fatigue, shortness of breath, heavy breathing, rapid breathing, exercise intolerance, and hypoxia.

 

Other options

 

 

Option A. Hypoxia: Hypoxia is a condition where there is a deficiency in the amount of oxygen reaching the tissues, a common sign of respiratory insufficiency.

 

Option B. Inability to speak: Inability to speak can result from severe airway obstruction, indicating significant respiratory distress.

 

Option C. Stridor during inspiration: Stridor is a high-pitched, noisy breathing sound resulting from the narrowing of the airway, indicative of respiratory obstruction and insufficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Signs of respiratory insufficiency include hypoxia, inability to speak, and stridor during inspiration, all indicating compromised respiratory function.

choices.text: Activated protein C

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady had an uneventful vaginal delivery. On postpartum day 1, she presented with postpartum hemorrhage and complains of visual changes and severe headache. A few hours after the complaint, she is found to be in an unresponsive state and is intubated and put on ventilation. On further examination, she has a BP of 60/40 mmHg and tachycardia, blood sugar is 48 mg/dL. Hematocrit and WBC count was normal. Which of the following drugs would help reverse this state? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Steroids

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation described—postpartum hemorrhage followed by severe headache, visual changes, hypotension, and unresponsiveness—suggests Sheehan syndrome. This condition arises from pituitary apoplexy, which is pituitary infarction secondary to severe blood loss during or after childbirth.

 

  • Sheehan Syndrome: This syndrome is characterized by pituitary gland failure due to substantial blood loss during delivery. The symptoms include persistent hypotension, tachycardia, hypoglycemia, lactation failure, headache, visual deficits, and in severe cases, shock, CNS hemorrhage, and even death.
  • Steroids: Hormone replacement with glucocorticoids (steroids) is crucial for managing Sheehan syndrome. Steroids address the adrenal insufficiency and help stabilize the patient’s condition. Initially, glucocorticoids are administered, followed by other hormone replacements as needed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inj. Dobutamine: Dobutamine is a beta-agonist used for managing cardiac failure and hypotension. While it may help with blood pressure, it does not address the underlying issue of pituitary failure and would not be the primary treatment for Sheehan syndrome.

 

Option C. Thyroxine: Thyroxine (T4) is a thyroid hormone used in thyroid hormone replacement therapy. While it might be needed later if thyroid function is affected, it does not directly address the acute symptoms of Sheehan syndrome, which is primarily managed with steroids.

 

Option D. Activated Protein C: Activated protein C is used in the management of severe sepsis and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), but it does not treat the pituitary dysfunction associated with Sheehan syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sheehan syndrome is treated primarily with glucocorticoid (steroid) therapy to manage pituitary failure following significant blood loss during or after childbirth.

 

Ref: Page 378, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: Which of the following is a water soluble contrast? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Iohexol

 

Explanation:

 

lohexol is a non-ionic, water-soluble iodinated contrast medium, used in various radiographic studies including CT scans, angiography, and myelography. It is known for its low osmolality and good safety profile, making it suitable for intravascular use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Barium: While barium sulfate is a contrast agent, it is not water-soluble and is primarily used for gastrointestinal studies.

 

Option C. Bromium: Not typically used as a contrast agent in medical imaging.

 

Option D. Calcium: Not used as a contrast agent. In medical imaging, calcium deposits may be identified by their radiographic appearance, but calcium itself is not administered as a contrast medium.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Naive B cells in Interfollicular zones

questions.text: Origin of B cell in CLL/SLL is: (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Naive B cells in Interfollicular zones

 

In CLL/SLL, B cells originate from naive B cell or Pre/Post Germinal Centre memory B cell. CLL arises in the lymph node.

 

DNA sequencing has revealed that the Ig genes of some CLL/SLL are somatically hypermutated, whereas others are not, suggesting that the cell of origin may be either a post germinal center memory B cell or a naïve B cell. For unclear reasons, tumors with unmutated Ig segments (those putatively of naive B-cell origin) pursue a more aggressive course

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Centrocytes: Centrocytes are B cells located in the germinal center of lymphoid follicles, where they undergo selection during the immune response. However, they are not the origin of CLL/SLL, as CLL/SLL originates from naive B cells or memory B cells, not centrocytes.

 

Option B. Extranodal mature Peripheral B cells: While peripheral B cells are involved in immune responses, the origin of CLL/SLL is not from these mature peripheral B cells but rather from naive B cells within interfollicular zones.

 

Option D. Bone Marrow Progenitors: Bone marrow progenitors are the precursors of various blood cells, including B cells, but they are not the immediate origin of the B cells involved in CLL/SLL. CLL/SLL originates from more differentiated B cells, specifically naive B cells in interfollicular zones or memory B cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The origin of B cells in CLL/SLL is primarily from naive B cells in interfollicular zones or post-germinal center memory B cells. Tumors originating from naive B cells, as indicated by unmutated Ig segments, tend to pursue a more aggressive course.

questions.text:
A healthcare worker in a remote primary healthcare clinic is reviewing the Vaccine Vial Monitor (VVM) on a vial of a vaccine that has been stored in the clinic for some time. Which of the following statements regarding the utility and interpretation of the VVM is/are correct?" [INICET NOV 2022]

 

  1. It is used for monitoring heat exposure of the vaccine by healthcare workers in primary healthcare.
  2. It shows cumulative exposure of the vaccine to the heat.
  3. It can be used to assess the potential efficacy of the vaccine.
  4. Calculation of the expiry date can be done using VVM.
  5. The expiry date of the vaccine can be relaxed if VVM is in an acceptable range.
  6. If the square and the circle are the same in color, then the vaccine can be safely used.
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 1, 2

 

  • Vaccine vial monitors (VVM) are heat-sensitive indicators routinely used to monitor heat exposure of the vaccine and determine vaccine viability as the vaccine vial moves across the supply chain.
  • VVMs change color as the vaccine is exposed to cumulative heat. If the color of inner square is similar or darker than the outer circle, the vaccine vial should be discarded.

 

Other Options:

 

3. A VVM can be used to assess vaccine potency and not vaccine efficacy.

 

4 & 5. Expiry date can’t be determined by VVM and has no relation to extend the expiry date.

 

6. If the square and the circle are the same in color, then the vaccine should be discarded.

 

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections and prior abdominal surgery presents to the emergency department with severe left-sided flank pain radiating to the groin. He describes the pain as sharp, intermittent, and worsening over the past 24 hours. He denies any fever, hematuria, or recent trauma. Physical examination reveals tenderness in the left flank without rebound tenderness or guarding. Laboratory studies show normal renal function, and urinalysis is negative for blood or infection. A retrograde ureteropyelogram is performed, revealing a significant narrowing of the left ureter as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ureteral stricture

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows dilated and clubbed calyces with a stricture at the left ureteropelvic junction, indicating hydronephrosis caused by partial or complete blockage of urine flow in the pelvicalyceal system. Ureteral strictures can arise from previous surgeries, infections, or trauma, leading to obstruction and subsequent swelling of the kidney and dilation of internal structures like the calyces. The classic imaging findings on retrograde ureteropyelography include dilated calyces and a tapered narrowing or blockage at the ureteropelvic junction, which explains the patient’s symptoms of intermittent, sharp pain due to the obstructed urine flow.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ureterolithiasis (kidney stone): This option is incorrect because ureteral stones typically cause acute, severe flank pain, often with hematuria, and are visible on imaging as radiopaque objects. The image does not demonstrate a stone but rather shows a smooth tapering of the ureter, consistent with a stricture causing hydronephrosis.

 

Option C. Pyelonephritis: This option is incorrect because pyelonephritis usually presents with symptoms such as fever, flank pain, and pyuria. Imaging in pyelonephritis might show renal enlargement or inflammation rather than ureteral narrowing or dilation of the calyces due to obstruction.

 

Option D. Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter: This option is incorrect because transitional cell carcinoma often appears as an irregular filling defect with potential mass effect rather than the smooth, tapered narrowing seen in strictures. Carcinomas typically cause painless hematuria and can obstruct the ureter, but the imaging features differ from the characteristic findings of strictures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ureteral strictures lead to hydronephrosis due to partial or complete blockage at the ureteropelvic junction, causing dilated and clubbed calyces. Retrograde ureteropyelogram is instrumental in diagnosing this condition, showing classic signs such as dilated calyces and ureteral narrowing. Management involves endoscopic or surgical intervention depending on severity and underlying cause.

questions.text: The region marked corresponds to the surface marking for which of the following structures:(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Right atrium

 

Explanation:

 

The region marked corresponds to the surface marking for the right atrium.

 

This image shows the mid-clavicular line, xiphoid process, and costal margin.

 

The examiner marks a laterally convex line that runs from the third costal cartilage, which is located about three spaces below the second costal cartilage (as shown by the sternal angle), to the sixth costal cartilage. The distance between this line and the sternal margin is around 1.2 cm. This imply that the area designated matches the right atrium's surface marking.

 

An average adult's projected cardiac borders onto the front chest wall form a trapezium shape. The percussion approach can be used to map this out by checking for cardiac dullness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thoracic duct: The thoracic duct typically ascends in the posterior mediastinum and does not correspond to the surface marking in the image which is more anterior and lateral.

 

Option C. Inferomedial bronchopulmonary segments: These segments are located more inferiorly in the lung fields and do not correspond to the area marked which is on the chest wall at the level of the heart.

 

Option D. Hilum: The hilum of the lung, where structures enter and exit the lung, is located more laterally than the area marked. It does not align with the vertical placement of the right atrium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The varying heart borders and the corresponding surface markings are as follows:

 

  • ﻿﻿Upper border: Slopes gently from the second left costal cartilage to the third right costal cartilage. It corresponds to the left atrium.
  • ﻿﻿Right border: Convex to the right and runs from the third to the sixth right costal cartilages, 1-2 cm lateral to the sternal edge. It corresponds to the right atrium.
  • ﻿﻿Inferior border or acute border: Runs leftwards from the 6th right costal cartilage to the cardiac apex which is located approximately
  • 9 cm lateral to the midline, often in the left 5th intercostal space or level with the 5th or 6th rib. It corresponds to the right ventricle.
  • ﻿﻿Left border or obtuse border: Convex laterally on the left. It extends superomedially from the cardiac apex to meet the second left costal cartilage about 1 cm from the left sternal edge. It corresponds to the left ventricle.

questions.text:
Arrange symptoms as in their order of appearance as seen in iron toxicity:(INICET MAY 2021)

  1. Pyloric stricture
  2. Asymptomatic phase
  3. Gastrointestinal bleeding
  4. Liver failure and hypoglycemia
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 3 → 2 → 4 → 1

 

Iron toxicity progresses through several stages, each with distinct symptoms that appear in a specific order. The stages are:

 

 

Treatment of Iron toxicity – Deferoxamine

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron toxicity progresses through distinct stages, starting with gastrointestinal irritation and bleeding, followed by an asymptomatic phase, then liver failure and hypoglycemia, and finally, bowel obstruction leading to pyloric stricture.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents to the paediatrician with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs). Upon further investigation, a micturating cystourethrogram is performed and which is shown below. The boy is currently asymptomatic and has no history of renal or bladder abnormalities. What could be the cause of the symptoms? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vesicoureteral reflux

 

  • In above case scenario recurrent urinary tract infections and the micturating cystourethrogram showing dilated ureters points towards the diagnosis of vesicoureteral reflux (VUR).
  • Vesicoureteral reflux is a condition where urine flows retrogradely from the bladder back into the ureters and possibly up to the kidneys.
  • VUR is a common cause of recurrent UTIs in children, especially when no other anatomical abnormalities are identified.
  •  The presented imaging findings and clinical history are consistent with VUR.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urinary bladder diverticulum: This refers to an outpouching of the bladder wall. It can be congenital or acquired, and these outpouchings can retain urine and be sites of recurrent infections. While bladder diverticula can cause UTIs, the described imaging findings (a dilated ureter) do not align with this diagnosis.

 

 

Option C. Urinary bladder hernia: This is a very rare condition where a portion of the urinary bladder herniates into the surrounding tissue or space. It is not typically associated with the findings described in the scenario.

 

Option D. Varicocele : A varicocele refers to an enlargement of the veins within the scrotum. It is not related to the imaging findings described in the scenario or the symptoms of recurrent UTIs in the patient.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) is a common cause of recurrent urinary tract infections in children. The condition is characterized by the retrograde flow of urine from the bladder into the ureters and potentially up to the kidneys. Imaging findings showing dilated ureters on a micturating cystourethrogram are indicative of VUR.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presented with a painless breast lump measuring 6.2 X 4.5 cm in the left upper outer quadrant and no axillary nodes. Core cut biopsy showed ductal carcinoma in situ. She underwent tumor resection with adequate margins and postoperative H&E showed DCIS with intermediate-grade necrosis and with 6-mm clearance on margins. What would be the next step in treatment? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adjuvant radiotherapy

 

According to Silverstein Van Nuys prognostic index which is used for DCIS, the total score is 9, and the patient would require adjuvant radiotherapy.

 

Age: 43 years (score 2), size: 62mm (score 3), clearance margin: 6mm (score 2) with intermediate-grade necrosis (score 2).

 

The Silverstein Van Nuys Prognostic Index (VNPI) is a prognostic tool used in the management of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) of the breast. DCIS is a non-invasive form of breast cancer, and the VNPI helps guide treatment decisions by assessing the risk of local recurrence.

 

The VNPI combines three significant predictors of local recurrence:

 

  1. Tumor size: The size of the DCIS lesion.
  2. Margin width: The width of clear tissue margins around the tumor after surgical resection.
  3. Pathologic classification: The histopathological characteristics of the DCIS, including features like grade and necrosis.

 

Scores on the VNPI typically range from 1 (best prognosis) to 3 (worst prognosis), with higher scores indicating a higher risk of local recurrence

 

The VNPI assists oncologists and surgeons in determining the appropriate treatment approach for patients with DCIS. For example, patients with a lower VNPI score may be candidates for less aggressive treatment, while those with a higher score may require more intensive therapies such as radiation therapy or mastectomy.

 

Score <7: No further treatment

 

Score 7-9: Adjuvant radiotherapy

 

Score >9: Simple mastectomy

choices.text: Safety in pregnancy
Dose adjustment in renal failure
Cost ratio from cheap to expensive
As per safety or therapeutic index

questions.text: Category A, B, C, D, X in drug classification is indicative of which of the following?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Safety in pregnancy

 

The categories A, B, C, D, and X are used to classify drugs based on their safety during pregnancy. This classification helps in determining the potential risk of medications to the fetus when taken during pregnancy.

 

Pregnancy drug category, which are indicative of their safety are as follows:

 

Category A > B > C > D > X

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dose adjustment in renal failure: Drug classifications for dose adjustments in renal failure typically involve guidelines based on the drug's pharmacokinetics and renal clearance. These guidelines are not categorized as A, B, C, D, X.

 

Option C. Cost ratio from cheap to expensive: Drug classifications based on cost are not typically denoted by the categories A, B, C, D, X. Cost-related classifications might be discussed in economic terms or based on generic versus brand name distinctions.

 

Option D. As per safety or therapeutic index: The therapeutic index of a drug, which measures its safety margin, is not categorized using the A, B, C, D, X system. The therapeutic index is a ratio comparing the toxic dose to the therapeutic dose, but it is not classified in this alphabetical manner.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classification of drugs into categories A, B, C, D, and X is specifically used to indicate their safety during pregnancy, helping healthcare providers to make informed decisions about medication use in pregnant patients.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man weighing 70 kg had a sodium level of 120 mEq, calculate sodium deficit? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 840 mEq

 

Explanation

 

The sodium deficit in the given scenario is 840 mEq.

 

Formula for calculating sodium deficit = 0.6 × body weight x (target plasma sodium concentration - starting plasma sodium concentration).

 

Substituting values as per the question,

 

Sodium deficit = 0.6 x 70 × (140 - 120) = 840 mEq.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Correcting sodium levels must be done cautiously, especially in cases of hyponatremia, to prevent complications like osmotic demyelination syndrome. Rapid changes in serum sodium can be dangerous, and adjustments should generally be made slowly, according to specific clinical guidelines.

choices.text: CT angiography of the lower extremities
Duplex ultrasound scan of the lower extremitiesDigital subtraction angiography (DSA)
Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) of the lower extremities

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with a 20-year history of heavy smoking presents to the clinic with complaints of right leg pain that occurs when he walks short distances and resolves with rest. He also reports a bluish discoloration of his right great toe that started a few weeks ago. He denies any recent trauma, fever, or sensory loss in the affected foot. Physical examination reveals diminished pulses in the lower extremities and cyanosis of the right great toe. Ankle-brachial index (ABI) is 0.6, indicating significant peripheral arterial disease. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosing this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Duplex ultrasound scan of the lower extremities

 

Explanation:

 

Chronic smoking significantly increases the risk of peripheral arterial disease (PAD), which often presents with symptoms such as intermittent claudication and bluish discoloration of the toes. Duplex ultrasound is the most appropriate initial diagnostic test for PAD as it is a non-invasive and cost-effective technique that provides detailed visualization of blood flow within the vessels. It uses ultrasound waves to create images and assess changes in blood flow direction and velocity, with high-flow areas suggesting stenosis or vessel narrowing. This modality is the preferred first step before considering more invasive or costly procedures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CT angiography of the lower extremities: This option is incorrect because CT angiography involves radiation and contrast administration, making it less ideal as an initial evaluation for PAD. It is typically reserved for further investigation when planning surgical or endovascular interventions.

 

Option C. Digital subtraction angiography (DSA): This option is incorrect because, although DSA provides dynamic arterial flow information and can be combined with therapeutic interventions, it is an invasive and costly procedure. It carries risks such as bleeding, arterial dissection, and renal dysfunction, making it unsuitable as a first-line test.

 

Option D. Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) of the lower extremities: This option is incorrect because MRA, while non-invasive, is less commonly used initially due to higher costs and less optimal image quality compared to DSA. It is typically used when more detailed imaging is needed after initial non-invasive assessments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic smoking is a major risk factor for peripheral arterial disease (PAD), which can present with intermittent claudication and ischemic changes like toe discoloration. Duplex ultrasound is the first-line diagnostic tool as it is non-invasive and provides real-time information on blood flow and vessel structure, aiding in the detection and evaluation of arterial stenosis without the risks associated with more invasive procedures like DSA.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient visits his family practitioner for a yearly examination. On examination, his BP was 190/100 mm Hg. His pulse pressure was 90 mm Hg. What would have decreased resulting in this increase in pulse pressure?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Arterial wall compliance

 

Pulse pressure is the difference between systolic and diastolic blood pressure, and it reflects the compliance (elasticity) of the arterial walls. In this scenario, the patient has a high systolic blood pressure and a normal diastolic blood pressure, resulting in an increased pulse pressure of 90 mm Hg (190 mm Hg - 100 mm Hg = 90 mm Hg).

 

Arterial wall compliance refers to the ability of the arteries to expand and contract with each heartbeat, which helps maintain a steady blood pressure. Decreased arterial wall compliance leads to increased stiffness of the arteries, which can cause an increase in systolic blood pressure and pulse pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myocardial contractility: Incorrect. While myocardial contractility can influence blood pressure, it is not directly related to the increase in pulse pressure in this scenario.

 

Option B. Stroke volume: Incorrect. Stroke volume affects cardiac output and overall blood pressure but is not the primary factor in the increase in pulse pressure observed here.

 

Option D. Cardiac output: Incorrect. Cardiac output can affect overall blood pressure, but the specific increase in pulse pressure in this case is more closely linked to decreased arterial wall compliance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decreased arterial wall compliance leads to increased stiffness of the arteries, resulting in higher systolic blood pressure and an increased pulse pressure, as observed in the patient.

questions.text: Plethoric lung fields are seen in: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. TAPVC

 

Explanation:

 

Plethoric lung fields are indicative of increased pulmonary arterial blood flow and are seen in:

 

  • Left to right shunts
  • TAPVC
  • TGA
  • Persistent truncus arteriosus

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tricuspid atresia does not have plethoric lung fields because in this condition right atrium is atretic.

 

Option C. Ebstein’s anomaly has atrialisation of RV, leading to small outflow tract, and resultant reduced pulmonary blood flow.

 

Option D. TOF has oligemia due to infundibular pulmonary stenosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TAPVC is characterized by plethoric lung fields due to the excessive flow of oxygenated blood returning to the right side of the heart and flowing back into the lungs instead of going to the systemic circulation, leading to increased pulmonary pressure and congestion. This condition is a serious congenital heart defect that typically requires corrective surgery.

choices.text: C and d

questions.text: Which of the regions marked in the image represents zone 4 of retroperitoneal hemorrhage? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A

 

Explanation

 

Zone 4 of retroperitoneal hemorrhage includes the portal and retrohepatic area. This zone is described in addition to the three standard zones of retroperitoneal injury. Zone 1 extends from the esophageal hiatus to the sacral promontory and is divided into supramesocolic and inframesocolic zones. Zone 2 extends from the lateral diaphragm to the iliac crest and typically involves distal renal arteries and veins. Zone 3 is confined to the retroperitoneal space of the pelvic bowl, including iliac arteries and veins.

 

 

Other options

 

Option B. C and D: These zones represent Zone 1, which extends from the esophageal hiatus to the sacral promontory and includes injuries to the abdominal aorta, IVC, and their proximal branches and tributaries.

 

Option C. B: This zone represents Zone 2, which includes the lateral diaphragm to the iliac crest and involves distal renal arteries and veins.

 

Option D. E: This zone represents Zone 3, which is confined to the retroperitoneal space of the pelvic bowl and includes iliac arteries and veins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zone 4 of retroperitoneal hemorrhage includes the portal and retrohepatic area, distinguished from the other zones based on its specific anatomical location and associated injuries.

questions.text:
Which of these are included in extra-esophageal symptoms of GERD? (multiple correct combinations) (INICET MAY 2024)

 

a. Asthma
b. Laryngitis
c. Excessive phlegm
d. Pulmonary fibrosis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is typically associated with symptoms such as heartburn, epigastric pain, and acid reflux. However, GERD can also present with a variety of extra-esophageal symptoms, which are manifestations outside the esophagus. These symptoms arise due to the aspiration of gastric contents or the stimulation of vagal reflexes.

 

  • Asthma: Nocturnal asthma can be triggered or exacerbated by GERD due to the reflux of stomach acid that can reach the airways, leading to bronchoconstriction.
  • Laryngitis: Laryngitis can occur when acid reflux irritates the laryngeal mucosa, leading to hoarseness or loss of voice.
  • Excessive phlegm: GERD can lead to chronic throat clearing and excessive phlegm production as the body attempts to clear the irritating reflux material from the throat.
  • Pulmonary fibrosis: Although less common, repeated aspiration of gastric contents can cause chronic inflammation in the lungs, leading to pulmonary fibrosis over time.

 

Other Options:

 

Since the  includes all options, there are no incorrect choices to explain in this instance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GERD can manifest not only with typical esophageal symptoms like heartburn but also with extra-esophageal symptoms such as asthma, laryngitis, excessive phlegm, and even pulmonary fibrosis.

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient with end-stage renal disease is scheduled to receive a kidney transplant from his son who is a compatible donor. What is this type of transplant known as?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Allograft

 

Explanation:

 

An allograft is a transplantation of tissue or an organ from one individual to another of the same species but with different genetic makeup. In this scenario, the kidney transplant from a son to his father is an example of an allograft because they are both human but genetically different individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autograft: An autograft is a transplantation of tissue from one part of the body to another part of the same individual. Examples include skin grafts taken from one area of the body to treat burns in another area.

 

Option C. Xenograft: A xenograft involves the transplantation of tissue or organs from one species to another. This type of transplant is not common in clinical practice due to the high risk of immune rejection and other complications. An example would be a pig heart valve transplanted into a human.

 

Option D. Isograft: An isograft is a transplantation of tissue or organs between two genetically identical individuals, such as identical twins. This type of transplant is also known as a syngeneic transplant and has the advantage of minimal risk of immune rejection due to the genetic identity between the donor and the recipient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A kidney transplant from a son to his father is classified as an allograft because it involves the transfer of an organ between two genetically different individuals of the same species.

questions.text: Identify the type of skull fracture in the given image? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fissured 

 

Image shows thin lines, which are not displaced. This is characteristic of fissured (linear) #

 

Fissured (linear) fractures present as thin, non-displaced lines and are the most common type of skull fracture, typically resulting from broad surface impacts, such as in road traffic accidents.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ring Fracture: Caused by a fall from height, presenting as a fracture around the foramen magnum.

 

Option B. Depressed Fracture: Caused by heavy objects with a small surface area, takes the shape of the weapon.

 

Option D. Hinge Fracture: Divides the skull into anterior and posterior halves, often associated with motorcyclist injuries.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Skull fractures 

 

  1. Linear fracture/ primary fracture/ fissured fracture                                                 
    • Fracture looks like a thin line 
    • Due to striking with a broad surface, e.g. ground 
    • Most common skull fracture, 
    • Usually seen in Road traffic accident
       

  2. Depressed fracture/ signature fracture 

    • Due to a heavy objects with small surface area . e.g. hammer 
    • Takes the shape of the weapon 

     

  3. Indented fracture / ping pong fracture / ponds #
    • Skull is depressed like a ping pong ball 
    • Seen in infants 
       
  4. Gutter fracture 
    • Long narrow depressed fracture 
    • Bullet passing adjacent to skull 
       
  5. Sutural fracture / diastatic fracture 
    • Sutures separate
    • Seen In <3 yrs of age 
       
  6. Ring fracture 
    • Cause – fall from height 
    • # around foramen magnum 
    • Associated # of vertebrae 
       
  7. Hinge fracture / motorcyclist fracture 
    • Skull divided into anterior and posterior halves 
       
  8. Spider web fracture / mosaic fracture / comminuted fracture 
    • Multiple fractures of skull

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with weight loss and fever. The patient reports a history of blood in the stool and vomiting two weeks ago. Upon examination, tenderness is noted in the right hypochondrium along with an enlarged liver (hepatomegaly). An abdominal CT scan reveals a lesion in the right liver lobe characterized by irregular borders, several partitions, and varied densities. What is the most probable diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Amoebic liver abscess

 

The most probable diagnosis in this case is C) Amoebic liver abscess.

 

1. Clinical Presentation:

 

  • The patient presents with weight loss and fever, which are common symptoms associated with liver abscesses.
  • A history of blood in the stool and vomiting two weeks ago may suggest an underlying gastrointestinal infection, likely to be amebic colitis.

 

2. Physical Examination Findings:

 

  • Tenderness in the right hypochondrium (upper right abdomen) suggests liver involvement.
  • Enlarged liver (hepatomegaly) is a common finding in liver abscesses.

 

3. Imaging Findings:

 

  • The description of the lesion on the abdominal CT scan is characteristic of an amoebic liver abscess. These abscesses typically have irregular borders, several partitions (internal septations), and varied densities due to necrotic tissue and pus formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyogenic liver abscess: Can also cause similar symptoms and imaging findings but will often present with high grade fever and chills, and is usually multiple.

 

Option B. Hydatid cyst: Typically presents as a well-defined cystic lesion on imaging and is caused by the Echinococcus parasite. It will not be preceded by a colitis type of event. It's less likely given the description of irregular borders and partitions in the lesion.

 

Option D. Hemangiomas: Hemangiomas are usually benign vascular tumors and are unlikely to cause the presented symptoms or imaging findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of clinical symptoms, physical examination findings, and the characteristic imaging features of an irregular, partitioned lesion in the liver makes amoebic liver abscess the most probable diagnosis in this case

 

 

ANCHOVY SAUCE – STERILE PUS SEEN IN AMEBIC LIVER ABSCESS

choices.text: Pedicled TRAM based on superior epigastric artery
Free TRAM based on inferior epigastric artery
DIEP based on deep inferior epigastric artery

questions.text: Identify the false statement about the flaps used in breast reconstruction?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) DIEP is a myocutaneous flap

 

Explanation:

 

The Deep Inferior Epigastric Perforator (DIEP) flap is a type of breast reconstruction flap that is derived from the deep inferior epigastric artery. The DIEP flap is a muscle-sparing flap, meaning it involves only the removal of skin, fat, and blood vessels (perforators), without taking any of the rectus abdominis muscle. This reduces the risk of post-operative abdominal weakness and complications, unlike the Transverse Rectus Abdominis Myocutaneous (TRAM) flap, which includes muscle. Therefore, it is incorrect to refer to the DIEP flap as a myocutaneous flap because it does not include muscle.

 

DIEP is a myocutaneous flap: This statement is false. A myocutaneous flap includes muscle tissue, whereas the DIEP flap spares the rectus abdominis muscle, utilizing only the skin, fat, and perforator vessels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pedicled TRAM based on superior epigastric artery: The pedicled TRAM flap stands for Transverse Rectus Abdominis Myocutaneous flap. It relies on the superior epigastric artery for blood supply, which remains attached (pedicled) to its original source. The flap, including the rectus muscle, is tunneled under the skin to the chest to reconstruct the breast. This statement is accurate.

 

Option B. Free TRAM based on inferior epigastric artery: The free TRAM flap involves the removal of a section of the abdominal tissue, including the rectus muscle, along with the inferior epigastric arteries. This flap is transplanted to the chest and connected to the chest's blood vessels using microsurgical techniques. This flap utilizes both the superior and inferior epigastric arteries. This statement is accurate.

 

Option C. DIEP based on deep inferior epigastric artery: The DIEP flap is similar to the free TRAM flap but does not involve the removal of the rectus muscle. Instead, it uses only the skin, fat, and perforator blood vessels based on the deep inferior epigastric artery. This design spares the abdominal muscles, reducing post-operative complications. This statement is accurate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The DIEP flap is a muscle-sparing flap used in breast reconstruction, involving the skin, fat, and blood vessels without including muscle tissue, which differentiates it from a myocutaneous flap like the TRAM flap.

choices.text: Genetic counselling and screening for BRA

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a family history of breast and ovarian cancer is seeking advice about her risk for developing breast cancer. She is currently taking oral contraceptive pills and is concerned about her risk. Which of the following is the next best step in management? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Genetic counselling and screening for BRA

 

  • A family history of breast and ovarian cancer in close relatives with one of the relatives having an onset before the age of 50 years indicates a high risk for breast cancer.
  • The next step in management is genetic counselling and screening for BRA.
  • This involves discussing various genetic testing options such as BRCA testing and multiple gene panel testing.
  • Genetic testing is recommended for high-risk women with a family history of breast or ovarian cancer, particularly if the diagnosis was made before age 50, if there are multiple affected family members, or if the patient has a personal history of breast or ovarian cancer.
  • Mammography is not the initial investigation of choice but can be used for surveillance after genetic screening.
  • Discontinuing oral contraceptive pills is not necessary as they do not increase the risk of breast cancer in women with a positive family history of breast cancer.

 

Given the patient's family history of breast and ovarian cancer, as well as her concerns about her risk, the next best step is to offer genetic counseling and testing for BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations. These genetic mutations are associated with an increased risk of breast and ovarian cancer. Understanding her genetic risk can help the patient make informed decisions about her healthcare, including potential surveillance and risk-reduction strategies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Routine mammography: Routine mammography is a screening tool for breast cancer, but it is typically recommended for women starting at around age 40 or 50, depending on guidelines and individual risk factors. While it's an important part of breast cancer screening, it may not be the most appropriate initial step in this case, given the patient's family history and concerns.

 

Option C. Stop taking oral contraceptive pills: While hormonal factors can be associated with a slight increase in breast cancer risk, discontinuing oral contraceptive pills may not be the primary step in managing a patient with a strong family history of breast and ovarian cancer. Genetic counseling and testing for BRCA mutations would provide more specific information about her risk.

 

Option D. Prophylactic surgery: Prophylactic surgery, such as a bilateral mastectomy or oophorectomy, may be considered in individuals with known BRCA mutations who have a high risk of breast and ovarian cancer. However, this step would be taken after genetic counseling and testing to determine the patient's risk and suitability for such procedures. It is not the initial step in management.

questions.text: Craniopagus is defined as the fusion of? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Head only

 

Craniopagus refers to a type of conjoined twins where the twins are fused at the cranium (head). This type of conjoined twin fusion involves the skulls but does not typically involve the face or the foramen magnum. Although the brains of craniopagus twins are usually separate, there may be some shared brain tissue, which can sometimes be discovered.

 

Craniopagus twins generally have fused skulls and meninges (the membranes covering the brain), making separation surgeries particularly complex and risky. These twins are genetically identical and are always of the same sex.

 

Craniopagus occurs in approximately 5% of conjoined twin cases, and the prognosis after separation surgery is often poor due to the complexity of the shared structures.

 

Types of Conjoined Twins:

 

  • Abdomen (omphalopagus): Fusion occurs at the abdomen.
  • Chest (thoracopagus): Fusion occurs at the thorax.
  • Top of head down to the belly button, facing each other (cephalopagus): Fusion occurs from the top of the head down to the belly button.
  • Head only (craniopagus): Fusion occurs at the cranium.
  • Pelvis, facing each other (ischiopagus): Fusion occurs at the pelvis with the twins facing each other.
  • Pelvis, side-to-side (parapagus): Fusion occurs at the pelvis with the twins side-by-side.
  • Vertebral column (rachipagus): Fusion occurs at the vertebral column.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Head and spine: This type of fusion is not characteristic of craniopagus, which involves only the head.

 

Option C. Thorax and spine: This type of fusion does not apply to craniopagus twins but could describe other forms like thoracopagus or rachipagus.

 

Option D. Thorax only: This describes thoracopagus twins, where the fusion occurs at the thorax, not the head.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Craniopagus is a specific type of conjoined twins where the fusion occurs only at the cranium (head), and these twins are genetically identical and of the same sex.

questions.text: What treatment should be avoided for a male patient in his mid-40s who was brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident, and presents with a heart rate of 120/min, respiratory rate of 30/min, and an X-ray image of his chest? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chest tube insertion

 

Given Scenario with x ray shows left sided traumatic diaphragmatic rupture with herniation of stomach. Nasogastric tube insertion, log roll, or epidural anesthesia can be done. However, intercostal drain should not be put as it would traumatic the herniated content.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The provided image displays an elevated left hemidiaphragm with stomach herniated into thorax, likely due to a diaphragmatic hernia resulting from blunt trauma in a road traffic accident.

 

  • Chest tube insertion or thoracostomy is not recommended in cases of diaphragmatic hernia and is contraindicated
  • Chest tube insertion is generally indicated for pneumothorax, hemothorax, chylothorax, pleural effusion, among others, but is contraindicated in the presence of pulmonary adhesions, pulmonary trauma, coagulopathy, and diaphragmatic hernia.
  • To insert a chest tube, the 5th intercostal space should be accessed anterior to the midaxillary line, within the triangle of safety, which is located above the level of the nipple and below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle.
  • Acquired diaphragmatic hernia does not contraindicate nasogastric tube insertion, log roll, or epidural anesthesia.

questions.text: Which of the following is a component of the neuromuscular criteria for maturity according to the expanded New Ballard score? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Scarf sign

 

The extended new Ballard score has a component of scarf sign which is a component of the neuromuscular maturity. The New Ballard Score is an extended to include extremely pre-term babies i.e. up to 20 weeks.

 

The scoring relies on the intra-uterine changes that the fetus undergoes during its maturation. Whereas the neurological criteria depend mainly upon muscle tone, the physical ones rely on anatomical changes. The neonate (less than 37 weeks of age) is in a state of physiological hypotonia. This tone increases throughout the fetal growth period, meaning a more premature baby would have lesser muscle tone.

 

Scarf sign: If the infant's arm is pulled medially across the chest (as shown in the image below)

 

 

  • In a hypotonic infant, the elbow will cross the midline.
  • In a term infant with a normal tone, the elbow will not reach the midline.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heel-knee test: Heel to knee test is not a part of ballard score

 

Option B. Finger-nose test: Finger to nose test is done to assess the cerebellar function.

 

Option D. Cubital angle: The cubital angle, also known as the carrying angle, is measured during the Services Selection Board (SSB) testing process. This has no role in ballard score.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The extended new Ballard score has a component of scarf sign which is a component of the neuromuscular maturity

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 2-week history of swelling, redness, and warmth in her right breast. She reports that the symptoms began suddenly, and she has noticed a lump that seems to have grown rapidly over this period. On physical examination, her right breast is erythematous, with edema and a peau d’orange appearance. A firm, tender mass is palpable and is mobile over the chest wall. There is no fluctuance or discharge, and no axillary lymphadenopathy is noted. Given the clinical findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Inflammatory breast carcinoma

 

Explanation:

 

The patient’s presentation of sudden onset breast swelling, erythema, warmth, and the peau d’orange appearance suggests inflammatory breast carcinoma, the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. This condition often presents with rapid onset of symptoms, including brawny induration, erythema with raised edges, and underlying edema. A skin biopsy is necessary to confirm the diagnosis by identifying cancer cells in the dermal lymphatics. Treatment typically involves a combined-modality approach, including neoadjuvant chemotherapy, surgery, radiation therapy, and targeted therapies such as hormonal therapy for ER-positive tumors or Trastuzumab for HER-2-positive tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Breast abscess: This option is incorrect because breast abscesses usually present with localized pain, fluctuance, and potential purulent discharge, often associated with lactation. The widespread erythema and peau d’orange appearance in this patient are more characteristic of inflammatory carcinoma.

 

Option C. Phyllodes tumor: This option is incorrect as phyllodes tumors present as large, firm, rapidly growing masses with a smooth, bosselated surface, but they do not cause skin erythema, warmth, or the characteristic peau d’orange appearance. They are generally not associated with systemic signs of inflammation.

 

Option D. Mastitis: This option is incorrect because mastitis, commonly seen in breastfeeding women, presents with localized redness, warmth, and tenderness, often accompanied by fever. Unlike inflammatory breast carcinoma, mastitis does not cause widespread edema or the peau d’orange appearance and generally improves with antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inflammatory breast carcinoma is an aggressive breast cancer subtype presenting with erythema, edema, and a peau d’orange appearance due to lymphatic obstruction. Diagnosis is confirmed with a skin biopsy, and treatment involves a combination of chemotherapy, surgery, radiation, and targeted therapies. Early recognition is essential due to its rapid progression and poor prognosis.

questions.text:
Mrs. Smith has been referred to the plastic surgery department for the reconstruction of a large wound on her thigh. After a thorough examination, the surgeon decides to perform a skin graft. While discussing the procedure with Mrs. Smith, the surgeon explains the difference between split skin and full-thickness skin grafts. Identify the true statement regarding split thickness and full-thickness skin grafts:(INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Primary contracture is more in split skin grafts
  2. Secondary contracture is more in split skin grafts
  3. Primary contracture is more in full-thickness grafts
  4. Secondary contracture is more in full-thickness grafts
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2, 3

 

Split skin grafts are partial-thickness skin grafts consisting of the epidermis and a part of the dermis, while full-thickness grafts consist of the epidermis along with the entire dermis, with portions of the sweat glands, sebaceous glands, and hair follicles. Primary contracture of the skin graft occurs due to passive recoil of the elastin fibers of the dermis in full thickness grafts. Since full-thickness grafts have more dermis (implying more elastin fibers), they undergo more primary contracture than split skin grafts.

 

Secondary contracture of the skin graft occurs due to the pull of myofibroblasts, and it occurs over time, when the transplanted graft starts healing. Full-thickness grafts have more ability to resist the pull of myofibroblasts, hence they have less secondary contracture than split skin grafts.

 

Primary contracture: FTSG

 

Secondary contracture: STSG

 

Thus, statements 2 and 3 are correct.

questions.text: Mrs. Johnson, a 54-year-old woman, underwent surgery for breast carcinoma last year. She now presents with painless swelling involving her left arm, which started 2 weeks ago. Upon examination, the affected arm appears swollen and feels heavy, with visible thickening of the skin. There is no warmth, redness, or tenderness. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lymphedema

 

  • Lymphedema is the most likely diagnosis given the patient's medical history and clinical presentation.
  •  Lymphedema is a common complication of breast cancer surgery, particularly when lymph nodes are removed or damaged during the procedure, leading to poor drainage of lymphatic fluid from the affected arm.
  • The swelling in lymphedema is usually painless, and the skin may feel tight or heavy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lymphangiosarcoma:  Lymphangiosarcoma is a rare type of cancer that can develop in the lymphatic vessels, often years after radiation therapy or surgery for breast cancer. Symptoms may include pain, swelling, and skin changes in the affected area. However, it is a very uncommon complication compared to lymphedema.

 

Option C. Venous thrombosis: Venous thrombosis is a blood clot that develops in a vein, usually presenting with symptoms like swelling, pain, and warmth in the affected area. In this case, the swelling is painless and is more indicative of lymphatic fluid accumulation rather than a venous thrombosis.

 

Option D. Cellulitis: Cellulitis is a bacterial infection of the skin and soft tissues, presenting with symptoms such as redness, swelling, pain, and warmth. The absence of warmth, redness, and tenderness in the patient's presentation makes cellulitis an unlikely diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lymphedema is a common postoperative complication of breast cancer surgery due to the removal or damage of lymph nodes, leading to poor lymphatic drainage.
  •  It presents as painless swelling, heaviness, and skin thickening in the affected limb.

questions.text: A patient presents with a 5 cm renal calculus causing severe flank pain. It is detected as a staghorn calculus. What is the best management? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy

 

PCNL is the preferred treatment for large and complex kidney stones, especially Staghorn calculi. It involves making a small incision in the patient's back to access the kidney directly. A nephroscope is then used to remove or break up the stone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ESWL (Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy): ESWL is a non-invasive procedure that uses shock waves to break up kidney stones into smaller pieces, making them easier to pass. While ESWL is effective for smaller kidney stones, it may not be as successful for very large (> 2 cm) and complex Staghorn calculi.

 

Option C. Ureteroscopic removal: Ureteroscopy is a procedure that involves inserting a thin, flexible tube (ureteroscope) through the urethra and bladder to reach the stone in the ureter or renal pelvis. While it can be effective for ureteric stones, it may not be the best choice for Staghorn calculi, especially those larger than 4 cm.

 

Option D. Hydrotherapy: This can be tried for stones up to 5 mm in size. Larger stones would get obstructed in ureter.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy (PCNL) is a minimally invasive surgical procedure used to remove large kidney stones. The following are some of the indications for PCNL:

 

  1. Large or complex kidney stones (> 2 cm) or hard stones (Cysteine) that cannot be treated with other minimally invasive procedures such as shock wave lithotripsy (SWL) or ureteroscopy.
  2. Staghorn calculi (large branching stones) that occupy a significant portion of the kidney.
  3. Stones that are associated with renal obstruction or infection.

choices.text: If the hands are visibly soiled
While moving from a contaminated site to a clean site during patient care

questions.text: A healthcare worker is performing patient care in a hospital setting. Which of the following is not a correct situation for using hand rub according to standard hand hygiene protocol? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) If the hands are visibly soiled

 

Hand rub, typically alcohol-based hand sanitizer, is not effective when hands are visibly soiled or contaminated with dirt, blood, or other body fluids. In such cases, healthcare workers should wash their hands with soap and water to physically remove the visible contaminants before using hand rub. This is a crucial step to ensure proper hand hygiene.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. While moving from a contaminated site to a clean site during patient care: Correct. Healthcare workers should use hand rub when transitioning from a contaminated site to a clean site during patient care. This helps prevent the spread of pathogens and maintain aseptic conditions. It's an essential practice in infection control

 

Option C. Before donning on gloves: Correct. Hand hygiene, including the use of hand rub, is recommended before putting on gloves. This step ensures that any potential contaminants on the hands are removed before glove use, reducing the risk of contamination during procedures .

 

Option D. During direct patient contact: Correct. Healthcare workers should use hand rub before and after direct patient contact to reduce the risk of transmitting pathogens to or from the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hand hygiene is essential for infection prevention in healthcare settings. Alcohol-based hand rubs are preferred in most cases, but soap and water should be used for visibly soiled hands and in cases of outbreaks of certain pathogens like Clostridium difficile. Hand hygiene should be performed before and after every direct patient contact, before donning gloves, and after removing gloves. Additionally, hand hygiene should be performed while moving from a contaminated site to a clean site during patient care. It is important to note that using hand rub is not appropriate if the hands are visibly soiled, as the rub cannot effectively remove dirt and debris from the hands. In such cases, soap and water handwashing is recommended.

choices.text: Insert a central venous catheter as the initial IV access of choice

questions.text: Before transferring the patient to the operating theatre, which of the following is necessary to do for a 60-year-old man who has been experiencing abdominal pain for the past six hours, has a BP of 84/50mmHg, RR of 26/min, saturation of 92% with 6 L of oxygen, and has extraluminal air in the abdomen on radiograph? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Administer 2 litres of crystalloid infusion

 

This is the correct option. The patient's low blood pressure (84/50 mmHg) and extraluminal air in the abdomen suggest a possible abdominal catastrophe, such as a perforated viscus. Administering crystalloid fluids is essential to address hypovolemia and improve blood pressure. The goal is to stabilize the patient's hemodynamic status and then perform an emergency laparotomy and repair the perforation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intubate the patient: While intubation may be necessary in some cases of severe respiratory distress or respiratory failure, it is not indicated in this situation.

 

Option B. Insert a central venous catheter as the initial IV access of choice: While establishing intravenous (IV) access is important for administering fluids and medications, inserting a central venous catheter is a more invasive procedure and not the initial step. Peripheral IV access can be established quickly and is usually sufficient for initial resuscitation.

 

Option D. Verify the diagnosis with CECT (Contrast-enhanced computed tomography): While a CT scan may be necessary for confirming the diagnosis and identifying the specific issue, it is not the initial step in managing a patient in this critical condition. Stabilizing the patient's vital signs and addressing potential hypovolemia should come first.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the given clinical scenario, volume resuscitation is crucial for maintaining BP as the patient has no history of trauma, indicating a possible bowel perforation.
  • Peripheral large-bore cannula may be used for initial volume resuscitation, and a central venous catheter may be required if vasopressors are planned.
  • Intubation may not be necessary since the patient is maintaining saturation.
  • CT scan may not be necessary as the provisional diagnosis of bowel perforation has already been established, and the patient's vital signs should be considered.

questions.text: Match the condition with the appropriate diagnostic test: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A 1, B 2, C 3, D 4

 

  1. Hirschsprung's disease is diagnosed by rectal biopsy, which is the gold standard diagnostic test for this condition.
  2. Posterior urethral valve is diagnosed by micturating cystourethrogram, which is a radiographic imaging test of the bladder and urethra during voiding.
  3. Choledochal cyst is diagnosed by MRCP, which is a non-invasive imaging test that uses magnetic resonance imaging to visualize the biliary tree.
  4. Intussusception is diagnosed by CT scan, which is a diagnostic imaging test that provides detailed images of the abdominal organs and structures.

 

Explanation:

 

A. Hirschsprung's disease: This is a congenital disorder in which nerve cells (ganglion cells) are absent from a segment of the bowel, usually the rectum or sigmoid colon, leading to a functional obstruction. Infants with Hirschsprung's typically have difficulty with bowel movements within the first days of life. The symptoms can include constipation, abdominal distension, and vomiting. It is diagnosed often in the neonatal period with a barium enema and confirmed with suction rectal biopsy showing the absence of ganglion cells.

 

B. Posterior urethral valve (PUV): PUV is a congenital malformation in male child where an abnormality of the posterior urethra prevents urine outflow. This can lead to urinary obstruction, distension of the bladder, and can subsequently cause damage to the kidneys. Common symptoms include weak urine stream, difficulty in urination, recurrent urinary tract infections, and failure to thrive. Diagnosis is usually made with a voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG).

 

C. Choledochal cyst: This is a congenital dilation of the bile ducts, often causing obstruction. Patients may present with the classic triad of abdominal pain, jaundice, and an abdominal mass, although not all these signs may be evident. Over time, choledochal cysts can lead to complications like cholangitis, pancreatitis, or even malignancy. Diagnosis is typically done with imaging like ultrasound or MRCP, and definitive treatment is surgical removal.
